channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia’s Gas Exports Are Expected to Drop by 50% in 2023
item.description: Estimates suggest gas exports by pipeline from Russia could be halved this year compared with 2022, which was an especially bad year. Here is what else we’re covering:
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier test fires a weapon on a firing range set up for troop training in Ukraine’s Donetsk region on Thursday.

item.title: What Soledar’s Salt, Lost in the Fight for Bakhmut, Means to Ukraine
item.description: Soledar, crushed in Russia’s long assault on Bakhmut, was only a little town. But its salt is a national staple, and a matter of pride.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bags of salt from Soledar in Kyiv in February. Some 20 tons of recovered stock are being sold to aid the war effort.

item.title: Khartoum’s Residents Cope With Paramilitary Fighters in Sudan
item.description: In parts of Khartoum that have been taken over by a feared paramilitary force, the civilians who have not fled endure an uneasy coexistence with fighters who are battling the regular army.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Footage released by the Sudanese paramilitary Rapid Support Forces purporting to show its fighters in the East Nile district of greater Khartoum, on Sunday.

item.title: Eduard Habsburg, Hungary’s Ambassador to Pope, Has Offbeat Résumé
item.description: Eduard Habsburg, Viktor Orban’s man at the Vatican, took the post after a career as a zombie movie screenwriter, novelist and cartoon producer. “I can get along with anybody,” says the descendant of emperors.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Stephanie Gengotti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eduard Habsburg, Hungary’s ambassador to the Vatican, at the chapel of Santa Maria dell’Anima, which holds the relics of some of his imperial ancestors, in Rome.

item.title: Ukrainian Troops Repel Russian Attacks, and Hope Western Arms Turn the Tide
item.description: Fierce fighting has yielded heavy casualties but little movement. Ukrainian forces need heavy weapons to change that, but they say it is no guarantee.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Stanislav Kozliuk
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A soldier from Ukraine’s 68th Jaeger Brigade fires a rocket-propelled grenade on a firing range set up for training in Ukraine’s Donetsk Region on Thursday.

item.title: Macron Honors Toussaint Louverture, Haitian Revolutionary
item.description: The French president paid tribute to Toussaint Louverture, the leader of the Haitian Revolution, but said nothing about the lingering effects of France’s slaving past.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron paying tribute to Toussaint Louverture on Thursday at the prison where he died.

item.title: ‘Best Friends’ Australia and New Zealand Patch Up a Major Difference
item.description: A reversal in Australian immigration policy toward New Zealand is part of a reset in relations, but some tensions remain.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia and his counterpart in New Zealand, Chris Hipkins.

item.title: In Israel, Ron DeSantis Promotes His Foreign Policy Credentials
item.description: The Florida governor, a likely contender for the Republican presidential nomination, stressed his strong interest in the country’s affairs, an issue that Donald J. Trump once made his own.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Ron DeSantis, the Florida governor, giving a speech in Jerusalem on Thursday. “Maintaining a strong U.S.-Israel relationship has been a priority for me during my time in elective office,” he said.

item.title: In an Indian Village, Cultivating Girls’ Big-League Dreams
item.description: A new $500 million women’s cricket league is offering the kind of opportunities that never existed before in India. The girls of one Punjab village are ready.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Atul Loke
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of a girls’ cricket team in the village of Dharoki in the Indian state of Punjab run two miles as part of their practice.

item.title: Brazilian Judge Bans Telegram App Amid School Attacks Inquiry
item.description: The Federal Police requested the app’s suspension because it failed to provide complete user data from two group chats that the authorities said had inspired an attack.
item.dc:creator: André Spigariol

item.title: Ukraine War ‘Turned Everything Upside Down’ in This Polish Town
item.description: A Polish town that was once occupied by the Soviets used to embrace its history with military re-enactments and Lenin banners. But “nobody wants to be reminded of Russia these days.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town of Borne Sulinowo, Poland, still has many reminders of its past life as a Soviet military city too secret to be named on maps.

item.title: Pope Gives Women a Vote in Influential Meeting of Bishops
item.description: The move is an important step by Francis as he strives for greater inclusiveness.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis at St. Peter’s Square in the Vatican on Wednesday.

item.title: Part of Swedish Research Rocket Lands in Norway, Causing Friction
item.description: The research rocket landed in a mountain range across the border, creating some rare friction between the two neighbors, with Norway saying protocols hadn’t been followed.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: The TEXUS-58 research rocket, launched by the Swedish Space Corporation, takes off from the Esrange Space Center in Sweden on Monday.

item.title: Boat Sinks in Mediterranean, and at Least 55 People Drown
item.description: The accident is the latest in a series of recent deadly accidents involving migrants trying to reach Europe.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: The Libyan coast guard undertaking a rescue operation on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Dark projections for Russia’s energy industry.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Part of a Gazprom pipeline in Russia.

item.title: What British Royal Moments Resonated With You?
item.description: We’re asking readers about the moments that changed how they view the royals, ahead of King Charles’s coronation.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Israeli Religious Right Demonstrates for Judicial Changes
item.description: Government ministers addressed the crowd and promised not to give up on the judicial plan, even as talks continue with the opposition for a compromise.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Demonstrators rallied in support of a government plan to overhaul the judiciary, in Jerusalem on Thursday.

item.title: U.N. Security Council Unanimously Condemns Taliban’s Treatment of Women
item.description: The resolution, an uncommon display of consensus on the Council, called for the Taliban to end their prohibitions on women working and attending school after sixth grade.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: An underground school hosted by a family in the basement of their house that allows girls above sixth grade to study, in Kandahar, Afghanistan, in November.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia’s Crumbling Gas Exports
item.description: Also, President Yoon’s address to Congress and Australia’s shift on New Zealand.
item.dc:creator: Mariah Kreutter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Russia has ceded its hard-fought position as Europe’s largest gas supplier to Norway.

item.title: It’s OK to Be Single, the Church of England Says: So Was Jesus.
item.description: In a new report, a church commission looking at families and households called on society to “honor and celebrate singleness.”
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.media:description: The Most Rev. Stephen Cottrell, archbishop of York, left, and the Most Rev. Justin Welby, archbishop of Canterbury.

item.title: From Alpacas to Yaks, Mammal DNA Yields Its Secrets
item.description: The genomes of monkeys, bats, whales and many other mammals are helping scientists tackle big questions about physiology, evolution and one very famous sled dog.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Russia’s Intelligence Agency for Detaining Americans
item.description: The United States also announced sanctions on Iran’s intelligence services, seeking to punish foreign governments for detention of Americans by cutting off access to the international financial system.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter, was detained in Russia last month and accused of espionage.

item.title: Brittney Griner on Gershkovich Arrest: ‘No One Should Be in Those Conditions’
item.description: Griner, speaking to reporters as she prepares for her next basketball season in the W.N.B.A., said she would continue to fight for those considered wrongfully detained by Russia, like the journalist Evan Gershkovich.
item.dc:creator: Kris Rhim
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Brittney Griner said during a news conference that her team had been in touch with the family of Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter detained in Russia.

item.title: Meet the Climate Hackers of Malawi
item.description: On tiny farms they’re testing creative ideas to stay ahead of the cascading threats — heat and drought, cyclones and floods — transforming their world.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Khadija Farah for The New York Times

item.title: The Fight Over the Debt Limit
item.description: House Republicans are putting the economy at risk to push spending cuts.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: House Speaker Kevin McCarthy has been trying to rally his party’s representatives behind his debt-limit proposals.

item.title: As Interest in Wellness Stirs Up the Cocktail World, This Executive Gets Her Shot
item.description: Heidi Dillon is on the vanguard of the fast-growing nonalcoholic-drinks sector and is reshaping how the male-dominated spirits industry perceives the shifting landscape.
item.dc:creator: Liza Weisstuch
item.media:credit: Clara Mokri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Heidi Dillon at the bar of Venus Spirits Cocktails & Kitchen in Santa Cruz, Calif. As the managing director for Distill Ventures, she is a leader and mentor in the growing no- and low-alcohol drinks sector of the historically male-dominated spirits industry.

item.title: Climate Change Made East African Drought 100 Times as Likely, Study Finds
item.description: The findings starkly show the misery that the burning of fossil fuels, mostly by rich countries, inflicts on societies that emit almost nothing by comparison.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: A water well near the town of Kelafo in Ethiopia, one of the nations hit hardest by the drought.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Biden and President Yoon Suk Yeol, center left, celebrated the 70-year alliance between the U.S. and South Korea

item.title: High-Ranking Iranian Cleric Gunned Down by Bank Guard
item.description: The killing comes as attacks on clerics are on the rise, following months of angry protests against the theocratic government.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Tasnim News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph of Ayatollah Abbas Ali Soleimani released by Iranian state news media on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: A U.S.-South Korea Nuclear Agreement
item.description: Also, Xi Jinping called Volodymyr Zelensky.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Biden welcomed President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea at the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: China’s Xi and Ukraine’s Zelensky Hold Talks
item.description: Volodymyr Zelensky has urged discussions with Xi Jinping since the Russian invasion, but in its official account of the phone call, China left out two words: “Russia” and “war.”
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Marc Santora and Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Ukrainian Presidential Press Service on Wednesday was described as showing President Volodymyr Zelensky talking by phone with Xi Jinping.

item.title: New Rules for Power Plants Could Give Carbon Capture a Boost. Here’s How.
item.description: The technology has struggled to gain traction, but strict new emissions limits for gas and coal stations could encourage broader adoption.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Michael Stravato for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carbon dioxide capture equipment at a power station near Houston that uses both coal and natural gas.

item.title: Leaked Documents Reflect Persistent Speculation on Putin’s Health
item.description: Leaked materials include unsubstantiated intelligence about a Ukrainian politician’s claim that the Russian leader is undergoing chemotherapy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Leaked documents suggested President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia might have been undergoing chemotherapy, although no evidence has emerged to support that.

item.title: A Fresh View of an Increasingly Familiar Black Hole
item.description: Radio astronomers have captured a wide-angle image of one of the most violent locales in the cosmos.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: A reporting team for an Italian newspaper comes under fire in southern Ukraine, and one journalist is killed.
item.description: Another reporter was hospitalized in the city of Kherson and described the attack to the paper, La Repubblica.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: Heat Pump Maker’s $13.3 Billion Sale Raises Questions in Germany
item.description: Carrier Global Corp., plans to acquire a unit of Viessmann Group that produces heat pumps, seen in Berlin as the heating solution for Germany’s green future.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Carrier Global Corp. said on Tuesday that it had agreed to pay 12 billion euros, or about $13.3 billion, to acquire a unit of Viessmann Group that produces heat pumps.

item.title: Where Were the Gatekeepers?
item.description: Finding lessons in the firing of Tucker Carlson.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Watching Tucker Carlson on Fox last year.

item.title: What Is the Synod of Bishops?
item.description: The assembly includes bishops from all over the world and takes years to prepare for. For the first time, an upcoming synod will allow women and laypeople to vote.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Cardinals, bishops and priests walk in a procession past Pope Francis earlier this month at St. Peter’s Basilica in Rome.

item.title: Ukraine Has Nearly All Combat Vehicles Allies Promised, NATO Says
item.description: Gen. Christopher Cavoli, also the top commander of U.S. forces in Europe, made the comments to the House Armed Services Committee.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian recruits training with a U.S. Mine Resistant Ambush Protected vehicle last month.

item.title: Germany Deems Youth Wing of Far-Right Party an Extremist Group
item.description: The party, Alternative for Germany, has been accused of radicalizing in recent years. Its youth wing is a threat to German democracy, the country’s domestic spy agency now says.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: People gather at a tent of the youth wing of the far-right Alternative for Germany party in eastern Germany in 2021.

item.title: Biden Vows ‘End’ of North Korean Regime if It Launches Nuclear Attack
item.description: During a state visit at the White House, Mr. Biden and President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea sought to bolster America’s nuclear umbrella guarding against threats from the North.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden welcomed President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea at the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: Aleksei Navalny, Top Kremlin Critic, Says New Charge Carries Life Term
item.description: The jailed Russian opposition leader said he faced a terrorism case that he described as “absurd.”
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny appeared via video link on Wednesday at a hearing in a Moscow court over separate extremism charges.

item.title: Facing China, the Philippines and U.S. Join in Biggest Military Drill Yet
item.description: After years of saying it would not choose sides, the Philippines is now asserting a need to stand up to China’s territorial moves in the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Ezra Acayan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Philippine Navy officers watching a Patriot surface-to-air missile fired during joint exercises with U.S. forces in San Antonio, Philippines, on Tuesday.

item.title: Relations between China and Ukraine have been uncertain since Russia’s full-scale invasion.
item.description: President Xi Jinping of China and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine last communicated in January 2022, less than two months before Russia invaded.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: China’s embassy in Kyiv last month. Before the war, trade and cultural exchanges had been growing.

item.title: Where Is Omar al-Bashir? Ex-Dictator Mystery Adds to Crisis in Sudan.
item.description: After speculation that Omar Hassan al-Bashir, who had been serving a prison sentence, had been freed, the army said that he was being held in a military hospital but provided no evidence.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Omar Hassan al-Bashir, center, who was ousted as the president of Sudan after three decades in power, at his trial in the capital, Khartoum, in 2021.

item.title: Biden’s Quiet Re-election Strategy
item.description: As Biden starts his campaign, we ask why he doesn’t spend more time in the public eye.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: President Joe Biden.

item.title: South Africa’s Shifting Stance on Whether It Will Quit the I.C.C.
item.description: As the International Criminal Court seeks to arrest Vladimir Putin, South Africa objects to its “unfair treatment” of some countries, but sends mixed signals about withdrawing.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa said on Tuesday that his political party, the African National Congress, believed it “prudent” to withdraw from the International Criminal Court. His office later issued a clarification of his remarks.

item.title: China Detains Taiwan-Based Publisher in National Security Investigation
item.description: Li Yanhe’s publishing company put out books that often cast a critical eye on China’s ruling Communist Party. He disappeared while on a trip to China.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien

item.title: Soviet Pop Art Duo Reunites for First U.S. Retrospective Since Their Breakup
item.description: The rebellious artists Vitaly Komar and Alexander Melamid founded their own artistic movement. They agreed to their first interview together in 20 years.
item.dc:creator: Sophia Kishkovsky
item.media:credit: Lauren Lancaster for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Komar and Melamid: A Lesson in History” at Rutgers University’s Zimmerli Art Museum in New Brunswick, N.J. The museum created the exhibit to highlight the duo’s collaborative work.

item.title: Bears, Binoculars and Bucket-List Birds: A 15-Day Tour in Ecuador
item.description: A customized itinerary allowed a group of birders to observe hundreds of species across a range of elevations, all while staying at comfortable eco-lodges.
item.dc:creator: Dorothy Spears and Alexis Rockman
item.media:description: Birds spotted at the various lodges, including hoatzin (bottom left) harpy eagle (front and low-center), paradise tanager (above eagle), chestnut-fronted macaw, (flying off to the right), and gray-breasted mountain toucan (flying off to the left).

item.title: Singapore Hangs Man for Conspiring to Traffic 2 Pounds of Cannabis
item.description: Human rights groups called the punishment far too severe and raised questions about due process.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A vigil in Singapore for Tangaraju Suppiah, who was hanged on Wednesday for conspiring to traffic marijuana. Singapore’s narcotics laws are some of the harshest in the world.

item.title: Inside Biden’s Renewed Promise to Protect South Korea From Nuclear Weapons
item.description: President Biden’s emphasis on America’s willingness to defend South Korea is a striking admission that North Korea’s arsenal is here to stay.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: A South Korean news program displaying a North Korean missile test.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Joe Biden’s bid for re-election.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Joe Biden arrives on stage to address the North America’s Building Trades Unions Legislative Conference at the Washington Hilton soon after his announced on Tuesday that he would seek a second term.

item.title: Russian Lawyers Ask Court to Ease Crackdown on Dissent
item.description: With thousands arrested for criticizing the invasion of Ukraine, the Kremlin has “criminalized dissent,” said a lawyer who asked the court to step in.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A peace symbol on a building in Moscow in January. Despite strict government censorship, Russians are finding ways to express dissent.

item.title: Russia’s Lavrov Hints at Possible Prisoner Swap for Evan Gershkovich and Paul Whelan
item.description: The channel to discuss detained American and Russian citizens, created in 2021, remains open, Sergey V. Lavrov said. But, he added, publicity “will only complicate the process.”
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: The Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich declared his innocence in a Moscow courtroom earlier this month.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Biden’s Re-Election Bid
item.description: Also, Ukraine prepares for a counteroffensive and South Korea’s president visits Washington.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Biden at in Washington on Tuesday.

item.title: Taliban Kill Head of ISIS Cell That Bombed Kabul Airport
item.description: Thirteen U.S. service members and scores of Afghan civilians died in the bombing as the United States was evacuating in August 2021.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: This image from a video released by the Defense Department shows U.S. Marines at the Abbey Gate at the Kabul, Afghanistan, international airport in 2021 before a suicide bomber struck.

item.title: Murdoch’s News Group Paid Settlement to Prince William, Court Filing Shows
item.description: A legal filing by Prince Harry in his own case against News Group claims his brother received “a huge sum of money’’ to settle phone-hacking allegations.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Princes William and Harry walked behind the coffin of Queen Elizabeth II as it left Buckingham Palace last year. Harry has said that William brought a claim against News Group, publisher of The Sun and the now-defunct tabloid News of the World, which was settled in 2020.

item.title: Is a UNESCO World Heritage Designation a Blessing or a Curse?
item.description: A spot on the UNESCO list — amid the world’s top natural and cultural locations — means a chance for economic benefits, but also for overtourism.
item.dc:creator: Ginanne Brownell
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Andrew Renneisen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lamu Town, along the Kenyan coast, was inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List in 2001. That list was established in the 1970s, and now includes 1,157 sites around the world.

item.title: Untangling Rosalind Franklin’s Role in DNA Discovery, 70 Years On
item.description: Historians have long debated the role that Dr. Franklin played in identifying the double helix. A new opinion essay argues that she was an “equal contributor.”
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Universal History Archive/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images

item.title: Here Are the Places Most at Risk From Record-Shattering Heat
item.description: It’s the regions of the world that haven’t yet experienced an off-the-charts heat wave that we should worry about, a new scientific study argues.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: The receding waters of the Jialing River in Chongqing, China, during a heat wave last August.

item.title: In Israel, a Memorial Day Marked by Political Divisions
item.description: While some politicians did not speak as planned at cemeteries, an appearance by the ultranationalist minister Itamar Ben-Gvir resulted in loud shouting matches between his supporters and opponents.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers and mourners observing two minutes of silence on Tuesday during a Memorial Day ceremony at the military cemetery in Beersheba, Israel.
